author: Google Gemini 2.0 Flash 001
Teoderick Contreras, Splunk
description: Google Gemini 2.0 Flash 001: The following analytic detects the creation of suspicious service files within the systemd directories on Linux platforms. It leverages logs containing file name, file path, and process GUID data from endpoints. This activity is significant for a SOC as it may indicate an adversary attempting to establish persistence on a compromised host. If confirmed malicious, this could lead to system compromise or data exfiltration, allowing attackers to maintain control over the system and execute further malicious activities. This rule was converted with Google Gemini 2.0 Flash 001.
false_positives: False positives may arise when administrators or network operators create files in systemd directories for legitimate automation tasks. Therefore, it's important to adjust filter macros to account for valid activities. To implement this search successfully, it's crucial to ingest appropriate logs, preferably using the Linux Sysmon Add-on from Splunkbase for those using Sysmon.
name: Google Gemini 2.0 Flash 001: Linux Service File Created In Systemd Directory
note: Investigate the creation of service files in systemd directories. Look for unusual file names, paths, and associated processes.
query:
sequence by host.hostname, file.path
  [process where event.type == "start" and process.name == "systemd"]
  [file where event.type == "creation" and file.name : "*.service" and
   file.path : ("/etc/systemd/system",
                 "/lib/systemd/system",
                 "/usr/lib/systemd/system",
                 "/run/systemd/system",
                 "/home/*/.config/systemd",
                 "/home/*/.local/share/systemd",
                 "/etc/systemd/user",
                 "/lib/systemd/user",
                 "/usr/lib/systemd/user",
                 "/run/systemd/user")]
